etymologies: mid 17th century (as a noun denoting payment for saving a ship or its cargo): from French, from medieval Latin salvagium, from Latin salvare ‘to save’. The verb dates from the late 19th century

definitions: rescue (a wrecked or disabled ship or its cargo) from loss at sea

examples.text: an emerald and gold cross was salvaged from the wreck

definitions: retrieve or preserve (something) from potential loss or adverse circumstances

examples.text: it was the only crumb of comfort he could salvage from the ordeal

shortDefinitions: retrieve or preserve something from potential loss or adverse circumstances

definitions: apprehend and execute (a suspected criminal) without trial

examples.text: those who are salvaged simply disappear from their homes or workplaces

definitions: the rescue of a wrecked or disabled ship or its cargo from loss at sea

examples.text: a salvage operation was under way

shortDefinitions: rescue of wrecked or disabled ship or its cargo from loss at sea

definitions: the cargo saved from a wrecked or sunken ship

examples.text: salvage taken from a ship that had sunk in the river

shortDefinitions: cargo saved from wrecked or sunken ship

definitions: the rescue of property or material from potential loss or destruction

examples.text: surgery resulted in the salvage of damaged myocardium

shortDefinitions: rescue of property or material from potential loss or destruction

definitions: payment made or due to a person who has saved a ship or its cargo.
shortDefinitions: payment made or due to person who has saved ship or its cargo
